thread.title: Major support under siege after China’s currency move
thread.title_full: Major support under siege after China’s currency move - MarketWatch

author: Michael Ashbaugh
title: Major support under siege after China’s currency move
text:
Editor’s Note: This is a free edition of The Technical Indicator, a daily MarketWatch subscriber newsletter. To get this column each market day, click here.
CINCINNATI (MarketWatch) — The market technicals are bending against the backdrop of China’s surprise decision to devalue its currency.
And while major support points are currently under siege, the S&P 500’s backdrop hasn’t technically cracked just yet.
Before detailing the U.S. markets’ wider view, the S&P 500’s hourly chart highlights the past two weeks.
As illustrated, the S&P has survived its third recent test of the 200-day moving average, rising toward the range top.
With Tuesday’s early downturn, the 2014 peak marks an inflection point, and is followed by more important support at the 2,080 breakout point.
Meanwhile, the Dow Jones Industrial Average has reversed from six-month lows.
From current levels, its first notable support holds around the 17,400 mark, and is followed by a deeper floor at last week’s low of 17,279.
And the Nasdaq Composite’s backdrop remains jagged, but stronger.
Consider that the index has thus far maintained significant support at the March peak, an inflection point better illustrated on the daily chart below.
Widening the view to six months adds perspective.
On this wider view, the Nasdaq has nailed major support at the March peak, closing last week at 5,043. This area matches its Greece-related range top, and the Nasdaq’s intermediate-term bias points higher barring a violation.
Moving to the Dow, its wider view is strikingly weaker.
Consider that the index plunged to six-month lows last week following a failed retest of the 200-day moving average.
Still, the Dow started this week with a steep single-day spike, and the quality of its rally attempt is worth tracking. Broadly speaking, significant resistance rests at the 17,800 mark — an area matching the 200-day moving average, currently 17,814 — and a close higher is needed to stabilize its backdrop.
And the S&P 500’s backdrop remains comparably stronger, following a third successful retest of the 200-day moving average.
Though the index is traversing a jagged six-month range, its longer-term bias points higher barring a violation of the 200-day.
The bigger picture As detailed above, the major U.S. benchmarks have diverged, and the current backdrop isn’t one-size-fits-all. The Dow industrials have recently reached six-month lows, while the Nasdaq Composite and the S&P 500 remain comparably resilient.
Beyond the headline benchmarks, consider the small- and mid-caps:
Starting with the small-caps, the iShares Russell 2000 ETF IWM, -1.25% is flirting with six-month lows, and its 200-day moving average, currently 121.40.
This is a developing head-and-shoulders top, a pattern that would be resolved with a sustained violation of support around the 120 mark. Looking ahead, a close atop first resistance around 123 would stabilize the IWM’s backdrop, while a break atop the July peak would wreck the bearish pattern.
Viewed in isolation, the Russell 2000 is vulnerable to a technical breakdown based on today’s backdrop.
Meanwhile, the SPDR S&P MidCap 400’s MDY, -1.23% backdrop remains tenuous, but comparably stronger.
Consider that it’s compressing between the major moving averages, topping Monday almost precisely at the 50-day moving average, currently 175.10.
